frame.name: Linguistic_meaning
frame.definition:
<def-root>A linguistic <fen>Form</fen> has a particular <fen>Meaning</fen>, possibly restricted to a particular <fen>Context</fen>. Some linguistic <fen>Form</fen>s, nouns and nominal expressions, also can refer to an object in the real or an imagined world, a <fen>Referent</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Form">"Unicorn"</fex> <t>denotes</t> <fex name="Referent">a mythological horse with a horn on its head</fex>.</ex>
<ex><fex name="Textual_location">In art</fex>, <fex name="Form">the word "oeuvre"</fex> <t>means</t> <fex name="Meaning">"the collected works of an artist."</fex></ex></def-root>

FE.name: Form
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Form</fen> is the formal pole of a linguistic sign.</def-root>

FE.name: Meaning
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Meaning</fen> is the sense of a linguistic <fen>Form</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Textual_location
FE.definition: <def-root>The FE <fen>Textual_location</fen> is used for expressions that indicate under which semantic, collocational, pragmatic or other circumstances a <fen>Form</fen> has a particular <fen>Meaning</fen>.</def-root>

FE.name: Referent
FE.definition: <def-root><fen>Referent</fen> identifies an object in the real (or a hypothetical) world that a linguistic expression is used to talk about.</def-root>

FE.name: Degree
FE.definition: <def-root>This frame element selects some gradable attribute of the <fen>Form</fen> and modifies the expected value for it.</def-root>
